q: What is the primary purpose of merging in Git?

Deleting the source branch before merging

q: When is a fast-forward merge possible?

When there are conflicts between branches

The tip of the receiving branch

By looking at the branch names

When two branches have the same name
When a commit message is empty
When the repository is too large

q: What is rebasing?

o: Rebase rewrites history; merge preserves it

q: Why do some teams prefer 'rebase' over 'merge'?

q: Why do some teams prefer 'merge' over 'rebase'?

q: What is 'git pull --ff-only'?

q: Why use 'git pull --ff-only'?
o: To prevent accidental merge commits when you expect a clean update

o: Invokes the editor before committing the merge (default for non-fast-forward)

o: Yes, but you might need to fetch more history if the merge base is missing

q: How do you deepen a shallow clone to allow merging?

q: In .gitattributes, what does 'merge=union' do?
o: Resolves conflicts by including lines from both versions (standard union)

q: What is the 'eol' attribute relevant for in merging?
o: End of Line normalization (CRLF vs LF) to prevent spurious conflicts

q: What does 'git config merge.renormalize true' do?
o: Runs a checkout/checkin cycle for all 3 stages of a merge to fix EOL issues

q: What is a 'criss-cross merge'?
o: When two branches merge each other's history multiple times, creating multiple common ancestors

q: Why is a criss-cross merge problematic?
o: It makes finding an optimal merge base ambiguous, potentially causing subtle conflicts

q: What is the 'recursive' strategy's solution to criss-cross merges?
o: It creates a temporary virtual merge base from the multiple ancestors

q: What is 'git merge-tree'?
o: Computes a merge without touching the index or worktree (server-side merge)

q: What does 'git merge-base --all' show?
o: All best common ancestors (if multiple exists, e.g. in criss-cross)

q: If you rebase, do the commit timestamps change?
o: Committer date changes; Author date is preserved (usually)

q: How can you force update the Author Date during rebase?
o: git rebase --ignore-date (changes author date to current)

q: What is 'git pull --no-edit'?
o: Accepts the default merge message without opening editor

q: What behavior does 'git pull --autostash' enable?
o: Stashes local changes, performs pull (rebase/merge), then pops stash

q: What is 'git merge --ff' (default)?
o: Allows fast-forward if possible, otherwise creates merge commit

q: What is 'git merge --no-ff' used for specifically in feature workflows?
o: To record the existence of the feature branch in history even if it could be fast-forwarded

q: Can you merge a tag?
o: Yes, it merges the commit the tag points to

q: If you merge a tag, what is the default message?
What is 'git merge --abort' strictly equivalent to?
o: Resetting to the state before the merge started

q: What happens if 'git merge --abort' cannot fully restore state?
o: It warns you; usually happens if uncommitted changes were present before merge

q: What is 'git merge --quit'?
o: Forget about the current merge in progress, leaving index/worktree as is

q: When would you use 'git merge --quit'?
o: If you want to keep the partial conflict resolution but stop the merge metadata

q: What is 'git merge --continue'?
o: Finish the merge after resolving conflicts (synonym for git commit in this context)

q: Does 'git rebase' copy notes by default?
What is 'git notes copy --for-rewrite=rebase'?
o: Configures notes to be copied during rebase rewrites

q: What does a 'content conflict' look like?
o: Modification to the same lines in a file

q: What is a 'semantic conflict'?
o: Code merges cleanly (textually) but logic is broken (e.g. function renamed in one branch, used in another)

q: How does Git handle semantic conflicts?
o: It generally doesn't; tests/compilation are needed to catch them

q: What is 'git diff --diff-filter=U'?
What is 'git checkout --conflict=diff3 <file>'?
o: Checks out the file again, recreating conflict markers in diff3 style

q: What is 'git checkout --conflict=merge <file>'?
o: Resets conflict markers to standard merge style

q: What is 'git rebase --keep-empty'?
o: Keep commits that become empty (start empty or become empty due to rebase)

q: What is 'git rebase --no-keep-empty' (default)?
What is 'git rebase --empty=drop'?
What is 'git rebase --empty=keep'?
What implies 'Already up-to-date'?
o: All commits in the source branch are already reachable from the target branch
You are on the main branch

q: Can 'git merge' decrease the number of heads?
o: Yes, by unifying multiple lines of development

q: What is 'git show-branch'?
o: Shows branches and their commits in a textual semi-graph

q: How to verify which merge strategy was used for a commit?
o: Check the commit message (often recorded) or deduce from parent count

q: What does a 'null merge' (merging with 'ours') effectively do?
o: Records a merge relationship but brings in NO changes (marks as merged)

q: Why use a null merge?
o: To discard a branch's changes forever but mark it as 'processed'

q: How to perform a null merge?
What is 'git merge --squash' commit message usually?
o: A concatenation of all squashed commit messages

q: Does 'git merge --squash' create a merge relationship (ancestor link)?
o: No, it creates a normal commit with no link to the source branch history

q: What is 'git rebase --committer-date-is-author-date'?
o: Sets the committer date to match the author date
Sets author date to committer date

q: What is 'git rebase --ignore-whitespace'?
o: Ignores whitespace differences when applying patches during rebase

q: What is 'git rebase --signoff'?
o: Adds a Signed-off-by trailer to all rebased commits

q: What is 'git merge --signoff'?
o: Adds a Signed-off-by trailer to the merge commit

q: What is 'git merge --verify-signatures' failure behavior?
o: Aborts the merge if side branch tip is not signed or bad signature

q: What is 'git merge --gpg-sign'?
What happens if you merge a branch that has reverted your own commit?
o: The revert is applied (your changes are removed)

q: How do you re-introduce changes that were reverted?
What is 'git cherry-pick --mainline 1'?
o: Specifies parent 1 as the mainline when cherry-picking a merge commit

q: What is 'git cherry-pick --mainline 2'?
o: Specifies parent 2 as the mainline (diff against parent 2 applied)

q: What is 'git merge --no-verify'?
What is 'git rebase --no-verify'?
What is 'git merge --verbose'?
What is 'git merge -q'?
What command helps visualize the merge base graph?
What is 'git show-ref --heads'?
What is 'git for-each-ref refs/heads'?
o: Iterates over all branches (useful for scripting merges)

q: What is 'git name-rev --name-only <sha>'?
o: Gives a symbolic name (branch/tag) for a SHA

q: How to check if two branches point to the same commit?
What is 'git diff --stat ...' used for before merge?
o: To see which files will change and how much

q: What is 'git merge --summary' (deprecated)?
What is 'git merge-index'?
o: A plumbing command to run a merge for files in the index

q: What does 'git update-index' do?
o: Modifies the index (staging area) entries directly

q: What is 'git checkout-index'?
o: Copies files from the index to the working tree

q: What does 'git rev-parse' do?
o: Parse revision (or other) arguments and turn them into SHA1 hashes

q: What does 'git hash-object' do?
o: Computes the object ID (SHA1) of a file, optionally writing it to database

q: What is 'git cat-file -p <sha>'?
o: Pretty-print the contents of an object

q: What does 'git ls-tree' show?
o: Lists the contents of a tree object

q: What is 'git diff-tree'?
o: Compares the content and mode of blobs found via two tree objects

q: What command creates a tree object from the current index?
What command creates a commit object?
What is 'git reset --merge'?
o: Resets index and updates files that are different between commit and HEAD, but keeps conflicting changes

q: What is 'git reset --keep'?
o: Resets index and updates files, but aborts if it would overwrite local changes

q: Which command manually creates a stash commit (without updating reflog)?
Which command stores a stash commit in the reflog?
What is 'git fast-import'?
o: Backend for fast git data importers

q: What does 'git verify-pack' do?
What does 'git unpack-objects' do?
o: Unpacks objects from a packed archive

q: What is 'git pruning'?
o: Removing unreachable objects from the database

q: What command runs garbage collection and pruning?
What does 'git reflog expire' do?
What is the 'histogram' diff algorithm?
o: An algorithm that tries to keep code blocks together (better for moved code)

q: What is the 'minimal' diff algorithm?
o: Spends extra time to make sure the smallest possible diff is produced

q: What is 'git diff --word-diff'?
o: Shows diffs inline at word level

q: What is 'git diff --color-words'?
What is 'git diff --no-index' used for?
o: Comparing two arbitrary files on disk (not in git)

q: What does 'git apply --reverse' do?
o: Applies the patch in reverse (undoes it)

q: What does 'git apply --reject' do?
o: Applies parts that apply cleanly, and leaves rejected hunks in .rej files

q: What does 'git apply --stat' show?
What does 'git apply --whitespace=fix' do?
o: Fixes whitespace errors in the patch before applying

q: What is 'git apply --cached'?
o: Applies patch to the index without touching working tree

q: What is 'git apply --directory=<root>'?
o: Prepends <root> to all filenames in the patch

q: What is 'git am --signoff'?
o: Add Signed-off-by line to the commit message

q: What is 'git am --Abort'?
o: Restores the original branch and stops the patching process

q: What is 'git am --resolved'?
o: Tells git am that you have resolved the conflict (synonym for --continue)

q: What is 'git clean -x'?
o: Remove untracked files, including ignored files

q: What is 'git clean -X' (uppercase)?
What does 'git clean -n' do?
o: Dry run (show what would be deleted)

q: What is 'git reset --mixed'?
o: Resets index but not working tree (default)

q: What is 'git reset --soft' primarily used for?
o: Undoing the last commit but keeping changes staged (good for amending/squashing)

q: What is 'git checkout -p'?
o: Interactively select hunks to checkout (discard changes)

q: What is 'git add -p'?
What is 'git stash -p'?
What is 'git commit --fixup <commit>'?
o: Create a fixup commit for use with rebase --autosquash

q: What does 'git rebase --autosquash' do?
o: Automatically moves and combines fixup/squash commits

q: What is 'git worktree add <path> <branch>'?
o: Creates a new working tree at <path> checked out to <branch>

q: How do you remove a worktree?
o: Delete the folder and run 'git worktree prune'

q: What is 'git checkout --detach'?
o: Check out a commit in detached HEAD state even if it has a branch name

q: What does 'git push --prune' do?
o: Deletes remote branches that don't exist locally

q: What is 'git fetch --prune'?
o: Removes remote-tracking refs that no longer exist on the remote

q: What is 'git branch -vv'?
o: List branches with upstream branch and tracking status

q: What is 'git tag --merged'?
o: Lists tags reachable from the current commit

q: What is 'git describe --contains <sha>'?
o: Finds tags that contain the commit (reverse of describe)

q: What is 'git show-branch --topics'?
o: Shows only topic branches (not the first one)

q: What is 'git log --topo-order'?
o: Show all parents before children (topological sort)

q: What is 'git diff --dirstat'?
o: Shows distribution of relative amount of changes for each directory

q: What is 'git diff --find-copies-harder'?
o: Inspects unmodified files as candidates for the source of copy

q: What is 'git diff --ignore-space-at-eol'?
o: Ignore changes in whitespace at EOL

q: What is 'git diff --anchored'?
o: Generate a diff using the 'anchored' algorithm (prevent syncing on specific lines)

q: What is 'git diff --inter-hunk-context'?
o: Combines hunks that are close to each other

q: What is 'git diff --function-context'?
o: Show whole function as context for each change

q: what is 'git merge --no-renames'?
What is 'git merge -X find-renames'?
What is 'git diff --numstat'?
What is 'git diff --shortstat'?
o: Output only the last line of the --stat format

q: What is 'git merge --log=100'?
o: Populates log with up to 100 oneline descriptions

q: What is 'git merge-base --octopus'?
o: Computes the best common ancestors of all supplied commits

q: What is 'git pack-refs'?
o: Packs heads and tags for efficient repository access

q: What is 'git prune-packed'?
o: Remove extra objects that are already in pack files

q: What is 'git count-objects -v'?
o: Provide verbose report on object database (size, count, garbage)

q: What is 'git fsck --lost-found' used for?
How can you recover a deleted stash?
o: Check 'git fsck' output for dangling commits

q: What is 'git maintenance start'?
o: Starts background maintenance tasks (gc, fetch, etc.)

q: What is 'git column'?
What is 'git range-diff' output format?
o: Dual diff showing differences between two patch series

q: What is 'git var -l'?
What is 'git version --build-options'?
o: Show build options used when compiling git

q: What is 'git help -a'?
What is 'git help -g'?
What is 'git whatchanged'?
o: Show logs with difference each commit introduces (deprecated, use log --raw)

q: What is 'git verify-tag'?
o: Check the GPG signature of tags

q: What is 'git mktag'?
What is 'git check-ref-format'?
o: Ensures a reference name is well-formed

q: What is 'git interpret-trailers'?
o: add or parse structured information in commit messages

q: What is 'git get-tar-commit-id'?
o: Extract commit ID from an archive created by git-archive

q: What is 'git name-rev --stdin'?
o: Reads SHAs from stdin and prints names

q: What is 'git show-index'?
What is 'git pack-redundant'?
What is 'git unpack-file'?
o: Creates a temporary file with a blob's contents

q: What is 'git var GIT_EDITOR'?
o: Prints the editor git will use

q: What is 'git var GIT_PAGER'?
o: Prints the pager git will use

q: What is 'git var GIT_AUTHOR_IDENT'?
o: Prints the author identity string to be used for commits

q: What is 'git var GIT_COMMITTER_IDENT'?
What is 'git symbol-type <name>' (if it existed)?
What is 'git patch-id'?
o: Generate a unique ID for a patch (ignoring whitespace)

q: What is 'git quiltimport'?
What is 'git request-pull'?
o: Generates a summary of changes to ask upstream to pull

q: What is 'git send-pack'?
o: Push objects over git protocol to another repository

q: What is 'git receive-pack'?
o: Invoked by git-send-pack to receive what is pushed

q: What is 'git upload-pack'?
o: Invoked by git-fetch-pack to send objects

q: What is 'git upload-archive'?
What is 'git cvsserver'?
o: A CVS server emulator for Git

q: What is 'git instaweb'?
o: Instantly browse your working repository in gitweb

q: What is 'git citool'?
What is 'git gui'?
o: A portable graphical interface to Git

q: What is 'gitk'?
